There are many colorful temples located outside of South India (Tamil Nadu) that are renowned for their architectural beauty and cultural significance. These temples are spread across different regions of the world and showcase a wide range of religious beliefs, traditions, and cultural practices. Here are some of the most famous colorful temples outside of South India:

  1. Angkor Wat, Cambodia: Angkor Wat is a Hindu temple complex located in the city of Siem Reap, Cambodia. It is one of the largest religious monuments in the world and is considered to be the epitome of Khmer architecture. The temple is adorned with intricate carvings, sculptures, and frescoes, depicting scenes from Hindu mythology. The temple is surrounded by a moat, and its central tower rises to a height of over 200 feet, providing panoramic views of the surrounding countryside.
  2. Pashupatinath Temple, Nepal: The Pashupatinath Temple is located in the Kathmandu Valley of Nepal and is one of the most revered Hindu shrines in the world. The temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The temple complex is composed of several smaller shrines and is surrounded by lush green forests, making it a serene and peaceful place. The temple is famous for its intricate carvings, sculptures, and paintings, which depict scenes from Hindu mythology.
  3. Borobudur Temple, Indonesia: The Borobudur Temple is a Buddhist temple located in the Indonesian province of Central Java. It is one of the largest Buddhist temples in the world and is considered to be one of the most important archaeological sites in Southeast Asia. The temple is composed of several levels, each with its own set of carvings and sculptures, depicting scenes from Buddhist mythology. The temple is also surrounded by lush green forests, making it a peaceful and serene place to visit.
  4. Shwezigon Pagoda, Myanmar: The Shwezigon Pagoda is a Buddhist temple located in the city of Bagan, Myanmar. It is considered to be one of the most important Buddhist shrines in the country and is known for its magnificent golden stupa. The pagoda is surrounded by smaller shrines, each adorned with intricate carvings, sculptures, and frescoes, depicting scenes from Buddhist mythology. The pagoda is also a popular pilgrimage site for Buddhists from all over the world.
  5. Baha'i House of Worship, India: The Baha'i House of Worship, also known as the Lotus Temple, is located in Delhi, India. It is a modern temple that is built in the shape of a lotus flower and is one of the most unique and recognizable religious structures in the world. The temple is surrounded by a large park and is considered to be one of the most peaceful and serene places in the city. The temple is a place of worship for the Baha'i Faith, a monotheistic religion that emphasizes the unity of all religions.
  6. Akshardham Temple, India: The Akshardham Temple is located in Delhi, India and is one of the most beautiful Hindu temples in the country. The temple is adorned with intricate carvings, sculptures, and frescoes, depicting scenes from Hindu mythology. The temple is also surrounded by lush green gardens, making it a peaceful and serene place to visit. The temple is dedicated to Lord Swaminarayan, a Hindu saint and teacher, and is considered to be one of the most important shrines for the followers of this faith.

Were temple gopurams in South India originally colorful or is this a recent change?

This one was very tough, but let me try answering from what I heard from older people in Tamil Nadu (I myself was born and brought up in Tamil Nadu but had always seen colors on Gopuram most of my life). I also read a few books and articles on Tamil temple architectural history

Many of the old folks I talk to believe that the temples were not colored until after 1950's. But reading some historical texts I found it was false. This one was very tough, but let me try answering from what I heard from older people in Tamil Nadu (I myself was born and brought up in Tamil Nadu but had always seen colors on Gopuram most of my life). I also read a few books and articles on Tamil temple architectural history

Many of the old folks I talk to believe that the temples were not colored until after 1950's. But reading some historical texts I found it was false. South Indian temples were colorful from very long back. This practice kind of diminished during the Nizam and Mughal rule and further reduced during British rule. Some temples during Chola period started toning down the colors since the colors reduced the intricacies of the carvings, but they still were colorful enough and were not always just rocks. Some temples do have just rock and were probably never painted like the Brihadeeswarar temple (built of Granite rock in 1010 AD by Cholas)

but some like the Madurai Meenakshi temple were always painted (first gopuram in existing structure was built in 1200 by Pandyas and rebuilt/expanded by Nayakars in 1600 AD)

Shows how this is also dependent on the era during which they were built.

The Divya Desams are revered by the 12 Alvars in the Divya Prabandha, a collection of 4,000 Tamil verses. Divya Desams follow Thenkalai or Vadakalai modes of worship.

Significantly, all the major towering temples of Tamil country built over the centuries have been consecrated according to agama rules.A temple is a place where an intense Cosmic energy is available for everyone to experience. Kindly note that Agamas are pre vedic.

Unfortunately, we need to site the History, 13th to 17th century, which distinguished the creation of Temples using Dravidian Architect in Tamil Country from other parts of India.

The beginning of Islamic invasions of the Indian subcontinent to create, thereafter expand the Muslim rule in the form of Sultanates and later the Mughal Empire.

Yes, Tamil country also witnessed few invasions.

Lot of Temples, including Sri Rangam, Madurai Meenakshi were destroyed during the invasion of Malik Kafur in 14th Century. But Tamil Country reacted differently than the rest. All are reconstructed by the Hindu Kings of Vijaya Nagara and Madurai and Thanjavur Naickers. What are some of the colorful temples in India?

India is known for its rich cultural heritage and vibrant architecture, and this is especially true of its many temples. Here are some of the most colorful temples in India:

  1. Sri Rangam Ranganathaswamy Temple - Located in the city of Trichy in Tamil Nadu, this temple is known for its intricate carvings and colorful gopurams, or tower entrances.
  2. Meenakshi Temple - Located in the city of Madurai in Tamil Nadu, this temple is dedicated to the Hindu goddess Parvati and is known for its towering gopurams, each covered in vibrant paintings and sculptures.
  3. Jagdish Temple - Located in the city of Udaipur in Rajasthan, this temple is dedicated to Lord Vishnu and is known for its stunning architecture and intricate carvings.
  4. Konark Sun Temple - Located in the state of Odisha, this temple is dedicated to the Hindu sun god Surya and is known for its massive stone wheel and intricate carvings.
  5. Virupaksha Temple - Located in the city of Hampi in Karnataka, this temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and is known for its towering gopurams, each painted in bright colors and adorned with intricate carvings.

These temples are just a few examples of the many colorful and vibrant temples that can be found throughout India. Each one is a unique expression of India's rich cultural heritage and architectural tradition.

I never used to believe in Astrology and would hate it when my parents would follow it. But as life is unpredictable, I ended up believing in it and became one of those. Below is my story:

I often come across this question from my friends in a very astonishing way, How come you into Astrology?, as I had mocked everyone who ever talked about astrology. However, today I can share my journey with everyone.

Back in 2013, I quit my job with Nomura to pursue my dreams but things didnt go as planned and I struggled for a year and exhausted my savings. To make ends meet, I went back to Mumbai and did some odd jobs as I was not getting shortlisted for any technology job interviews, citing a gap of one year. After some networking, an old colleague referred me to BNP Paribas and I got the job at a pay cut.

After working there for a year, I got in touch with one of my school friends, who later went to IIT Delhi, and we both planned to start an IT services company. It was time to put down the papers yet again, and I typed the resignation letter with full enthusiasm (that time I didnt have to look for email templates on Google) but I got very anxious before sending it, as the old struggling days started haunting me.

As I was staring dead at the resignation email, one of my colleagues came over and inquired, Is everything okay? You look lost. I showed her my resignation letter and told her how my negative thoughts are not letting me do what I wanted to.

She looked at me with empathy and said, I can see your birth chart and tell you what to do as per Astrology. What are your birth details? and she opened one very badly designed app on her phone to input my details. I was shocked and amused at the same time. I promised myself to hire good UI/UX designers to develop better apps than that).

Seriously? Do you think I believe in all this? Padhe likhe hoke aap andh vishwas faila rahe ho! I scolded her but I wished I could get some help.

She waited for me to complete and demanded, Are you done? Now tell me your birth details. I dont care if you believe or not but let me try to help. I shared the details as I would rather not mess with a senior. But knowing her coding skills, I could totally judge that she would screw up in Astrology as well.

As she was analysing my chart, I waited curiously to know the outcome, the way I had waited for my 10th standard board results. There is something about Astrology, it doesnt matter whether you believe in it or not, but it fascinates you like nothing else. However, as I didnt trust her and would never have liked to take a biased decision based on Astrology, so I quickly sent the resignation letter and locked my screen. Meanwhile, she was done with her calculations and it was time for the results.

You are Leo Ascendant and your Sun is exalted I interrupted her in between and asked, I dont understand all this. Tell me something about the past to make me believe you, I was such a spoiler.

Beta, jitna tu bhaagta hai na isse, aage jake utna jaada believe karega (Dear, as much as you are mocking this today, you will believe in it much more, in future), She mocked me this time but after hearing that I was convinced she knew Astrology as good as Database designing, as I would never do that.

You dont choose Astrology, Astrology chooses you

Then she told me many things about my past to make her point including the date of my accident in school days, which was shocking. And once she observed the change in my body language, she stopped telling about the past and came to the main question. She not only predicted the past correctly but was also such a nice observer of behaviour. Oh God! Why the hell was she a MySQL developer?

Yes, you can quit your job as the next two years are very promising for an IT business as per the placement of Saturn and Rahu, she smiled as she made the prediction. I am still not sure if that smile was for a positive prediction or for the virtual win over me.

Just two years?, I exclaimed with a sheepish laugh as I had to pretend that I was not interested.

Like every other story, this story was also filled with some twist and turns. The twist was that my business partner might leave after two years from then and I would face some issues in resuming the business and it might take a year to pivot to a new venture, But you will make it she assured after observing my not-so-good body language.

You can press the send button, she finally said something with a real smile as she observed that I wasnt mocking anymore and had surrendered myself, unlike a Leo.

After that, I served my notice period and came to Noida and started an IT services company named CodeYeti in April 2015. We managed to scale up very quickly to 45 employees, serving about 15-20 clients at a time and clocked a revenue of $0.5 million in the first year itself. We started working for big enterprises like Yamaha, GreenPly along with startups.

Everything was going well until my partner told me that he is not getting a kick from the services business and wanted to do a tech product. We spent the next six months on two products but ended up wasting capital as nothing seemed to work and he finally quit in March 2017 to do something else.

And that reminded me about the prediction, my ex-colleague had made about my partners exit. I called her after a gap of two years (Lets just assume that I was busy and was not bad at keeping in touch) and told her about the prediction.

I could sense the happiness in her voice as her prediction came true but she showed concern as it was a loss for me. To my surprise, she knew everything about CodeYeti as she followed our social media channels and congratulated me for what we had achieved in such a short duration.

Do you want me to check your chart again? she inquired.

I paused for a moment and proposed an idea, How about I start a product in the field of Astrology and I become your first customer? She halted for a few seconds and said, HmmmI had quit my job four months back for some personal reasons, and I can take out some time to work with you but I wont be very active, so you will have to find more astrologers. I can connect you with a few in my network

Do all temples in Tamil Nadu look the same?

Superficially YES. No two Temples follow the same design, superstructure etc. It all depends on the Satapathy (temple architect) who designed them. The same stapathi would ensure that each of his Temples are unique but has his signature stamped on them!

What is special about the Thennangoor Temple in Tamil Nadu?

Thennangur Panduranga Temple is located in the Thennangur village in the district of Tiruvannamalai in Kanchipuram. The town is also known as the birthplace of Goddess Meenakshi. Thennangur Panduranga Temple is dedicated to Panduranga and his consort Rukmayee. It attracts tourists from all over the world for its religious importance, its unique architecture and the divine idols of Lord Panduranga and Rukmayee. Thennangur Panduranga Temple is located in the Thennangur village in the district of Tiruvannamalai in Kanchipuram. The town is also known as the birthplace of Goddess Meenakshi. Thennangur Panduranga Temple is dedicated to Panduranga and his consort Rukmayee. It attracts tourists from all over the world for its religious importance, its unique architecture and the divine idols of Lord Panduranga and Rukmayee. The main idol of the temple was installed by Swami Haridas Giri which he had brought along with him from Pandharpur about 500 years ago. The striking temple also houses an idol of Achyutraja Perumal which is a rare find India. It is said that no temple in India has an idol of Achyutraja Perumal, making it a unique find in the country.

The idols are grand and elegantly dressed with great enthusiasm and spirit in colourful clothes and beautiful jewellery. The sight of the beautifully decorated idols is a treat to the eyes. Many get mesmerised by the dazzling beauty of the idols and witness, not just the blessings of the Almighty, but also the magical vibe in the temple atmosphere. One can see a beautiful merger of the Orthodox Sampraday and the Bhajan Sampraday here. It is believed that the Lord blesses newlywed couples hence most families choose the Maha Mandap inside the temple complex as their wedding venue. It is also believed that Lord Panduranga appears in different forms on special occasions. The Thennangur Panduranga Temple is thus of immense religious and spiritual importance to the devotees travel miles to visit and offer their prayers

Which are the best temples in South India?

South Indian temples are some of the finest examples of rich ancient Indian heritage, culture, unique rituals, historical facts and unique artifacts along with being pilgrimage sites.

You can see one common thing among all the temples architectural style that is the tallest towers situated at the entrance of almost every temple but you can find different-different rituals, rich history and architectural style behind every south Indian temple.

Here are some of the best South Indian temples:

Meenakshi Temple of Madurai:

Meenakshi temple of Madurai, TamilNadu is a fine example of Dravidian architecture style dedicated to Parvati (Meenakshi is her other name) built in 6th century BC by Kulasekarer Pandya. Music Pillars, gateway towers are the prime attractions at the temple.

Shore Temple, Mahabalipuram:

Shore temple of Mahabalipuram, Chennai is a UNESCO world heritage site of India. Temple built in the Dravidian architectural style established between 700728 AD by Narasimha Varma. Temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva.

Kapaleshwar Temple, Chennai:

Kapaleshwar temple of Chennai is another fine example of the Dravidian architecture style dedicated to Lord Shiva. The temple built in 7th century by the rulers of Tuluva dynasty.

Brihadeshwara Temple, Thanjavur:

Brihadeshwara Temple of Thanjavur, Tamil Nadu is locally known as the Big Temple built in 1010 CE by ruler Rajas Chola. The temple is one of the finest examples of Tamil architecture and dedicated to Lord Shiva. Nandi statue and 108 dance Karanas are the prime attractions of the temple.

Ramanathaswamy Temple, Rameswaram:

Ramanathaswamy temple of Rameshwaram, Tamil Nadu is a famous temple structured in the Dravidian architecture style built in 12th century by Pandya and Jaffna kings. The temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva.

Everyone can witness the beauty of famous South Indian temples with the perfectly crafted South Indian temple tour itinerary.

If you are visiting Tamil Nadu from other state, then I would recommend you to reach Chennai the evening of day before Day 1 or early morning of Day 1.

Thanks for A2A

Most of the famous temples of Tamil Nadu are situated in Kanchipuram, Trichy-Thanjavur and Madurai.

If you are visiting Tamil Nadu from other state, then I would recommend you to reach Chennai the evening of day before Day 1 or early morning of Day 1.

Day 1 : Travel to Kanchipuram from Chennai. In Kanchipuram famous temples are Kanchi Kamshi Amman Temple, Ekambareswarar Temple, Ullagantha Perumal Temple.

Complete these temples by afternoon and travel to Chidambaram. The famous Chidbarnathar temple is both architectural and devotional treat.

From there travel to Thanjavur and have a night stay.

Day 2 : Visit Brihadeeswarar temple and later few other temples nearby it. There are lots of temples near Thanjavur and Kumbakonam. By evening travel to Srirangam and stay in Srirangam at night.

Day 3 : In morning visit Sri Ranganathar Perumal Temple, Samyapuram and Thiruvanaikal Temple in the morning.

Then travel to Madurai, on the way you can visit Azhagar Kovil and Palamuthircholai. In evening visit Madurai Meenakshi temple.

Few Tips :

  1. Travel by road, the road facilities are very good.
  2. Search in Google for the temple timings or ask the locals for it while travelling and skip the temples if it is closed.
  3. Donot compensate on travel time.
  4. Have food in restaurants in the highways.

Have a wonderful time visiting Tamil Nadu. :)

Why are there so many temples in Tamil Nadu, India? What is the significance of these temples, and what do they represent?

For thousands of years what is now modern India was ruled by dynasties which ruled areas, some large and some small. And some of these dynasties were temple builders, especially the case in what is now Tamil Nadu. Thus, many of the most magnificent temples in Tamil Nadu were built by the Chola Dynasty They represent devotion to a particular deity, in the case of the Cholas - Lord Shiva.

Why do most of the South Indian temples have colorful statues on them?

Not all, not even most south indian temples. Only those which came under chola, chera and pandiyan influence ( including later srivaishnavas). Fine sculpted stone is not painted. Painting done only on plastered surfaces. Large temple architecture spread starting with Pattadakal, and most were in sculpted stone; it would been foolish to plaster paint them.

Where is Meenakshi Temple in India?

for starters I will treat your question as genuine. Meenakshi is the consort of Lord Shiva, she belongs to Madurai and was a woman endowed with great intelligence, charm and beauty, especially her eyes which were in the shape of fish, so she was given the name Meenakshi (Meen is fish in Sanskrit as well as Tamil and nakshi broadly means beauty, facial features and eyes).

Frankly, there arent too many temples having the shrine for Meenakshi, but there are temples where the central female deity i.e. Goddess Parvathi is also at times called Meenakshi, especially if her hair has a kondai (ball sha

for starters I will treat your question as genuine. Meenakshi is the consort of Lord Shiva, she belongs to Madurai and was a woman endowed with great intelligence, charm and beauty, especially her eyes which were in the shape of fish, so she was given the name Meenakshi (Meen is fish in Sanskrit as well as Tamil and nakshi broadly means beauty, facial features and eyes).

Frankly, there arent too many temples having the shrine for Meenakshi, but there are temples where the central female deity i.e. Goddess Parvathi is also at times called Meenakshi, especially if her hair has a kondai (ball shaped decoration, that is tilting to the left (or right) like the one below:

here is another specimen:

Usually Goddess Parvathi is also decorated as above in many temples housing Lord Shiva and Parvathi. A specific and possibly a most important as well as largest temples of Lord Shiva and Meenakshi is an ancient Pandyan temple in their capital Madurai, that is said to have existed as a small shrine from the BC era - some describe Meenakshi as also being an ancient queen of Madurai who got married to Lord Shiva..

So if you are looking for the most important temple dedicated to Meenakshi, it is the Meenakshi Temple at Madurai, Tamil Nadu, it was expanded and reconstructed during the rule of the Nayakas (former vassals of Vijayanagara kingdom), mainly from around 1560 AD to about 1750 AD. Otherwise, its earliest existence has been recorded in Sangam Literature of 5th to 8th centuries AD, where it has been described as an important temple of very ancient traditions lasting several centuries, which means that the earliest known existence of the Meenakshi temple can be taken back to at least the 1st Century AD, if not earlier than that. Its antiquity is respected even by the Railways as a train in the MG era that ran between Madurai and Tirupati (before that it ran between Tiruchy and Tirupati) was named the Meenakshi Express. Now it runs as a BG express between Tirupati and Rameswaram through Thanjavur-Tiruchy and Madurai.
